title: Wooden sculpture depicting music and dancing by Felicien Levesque, donated by Dan Mills and Gail Skudera
description: A 20th century wooden sculpture that depicts music and dancing created by Felicien Levesque. It is housed in the Franco-American Collection at the University of Southern Maine. It shows how wood was a medium of choice for artists in the Northeast especially in Maine and Canada. It also shows how music and dance were important to the Franco-American community along with artwork.
creator: Felicien Levesque
subject: Artwork; Franco-American
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. title: Workers building the Lewiston Maine Canals
description: Workers in the 19th century building the Lewiston Maine canals. They used both wood and stone to construct the canals. This is important to demonstrate that many of the jobs of the day were labor intensive and involved the medium of wood. This is why much of the artwork of the day was done in wood because it was an easily accessible medium for people to use. Both amateur and professional artists used wood as it was something they were familar with.
subject: Photograph; Canal workers; Franco-American community

title: Franco-American Centre members and local Lewiston dignitaries surrounding the Paysan Québécois statue by Jean-Julien Bourgault
description: This image shows Centre members and local Lewiston dignitaries surrounding the Le Paysan Québécois statue. From left to right, Rita Pinette Croteau (1920-1988), Raymond Duprey, Loretta Pinette Duprey and on the other side of the statue, Mayor of Lewiston, Lillian Caron (1931-1995) and Dominican Father Reverend Robert Comtois. According to notations on the back of the image, this picture was taken during an exhibition of the statue at the Blaine House in Augusta. This image is significant because it highlights the impact that J.J. Bourgault had on the Franco-American community at the time. It shows how excited the community was to house his artwork and be able to put the artwork on display. It is a great representation of the community at the time.
subject: Photograph; J.J. Bourgault Artwork; Franco-American community

title: Newspaper Article of Jean Julien Bourgault Exhibit
description: This newspaper article described the closing of the J.J. Bourgault exhibit at Bates College in 1977. This exhibit was important to the community because they got to meet the artist and see the incredible work he created. There were a couple different newspaper articles describing him and his artwork around this period. The arts were an important part of the Franco-American community so it makes sense that having a French-Canadian artist come into town was a big deal for the community. With the help of the Franco-American Centre and Bates College the exhibit was able to occur.
creator: Franco-American Centre
subject: J.J. Bourgault, Newspaper, Franco-American Community

title: Photo of Paysan Quebecois Statue
description: This image shows the wood carved statue titled Le Paysan Québécois done by Jean Julien Bourgault. The carving was completed in 1976 and was done for Maine's celebration of the National Bicentennial. It is extremely detailed and shows the talent of Bourgault. It was first displayed in the State House in Augusta then later donated to the Franco-American Collection who now houses the statue. The artist was from Canada so it makes sense that it would be housed in the collection that celebrates the Franco-American community.
creator: Jean Julien Bourgault

title: Photo of Paysan Quebecois Statue by J.J. Bourgault
description: This is an image of the statue called Le Paysan Québécois done by J.J. Bourgault. Bourgault was an artist from Quebec who was known for his incredible wood carvings. He would carve ordinary subjects such as farmers or fishermen. This statue shows the complexity of his artwork.
creator: Jean Julien Bourgault

title: Signed pamphlet of Jean Julien Bourgault Exhibit at Bates College
description: This is a signed cover page of the pamphlet describing the J.J. Bourgault exhibit at Bates College. This exhibit brought people out from the Lewiston-Auburn community along with from all over the state. It was a great way to showcase this artist's artwork and the importance of woodcarving. Wood was an easily accessible medium so it is likely that there were many amateur wood carvers in the community. The exhibit may have even inspired others to become wood carvers.
creator: Franco-American Centre
